chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Government should ensure everyone has access to a core set of essential health services and strong protection from catastrophic medical bills, without requiring a one-size-fits-all system. It should set clear national standards for coverage and equity, use its purchasing power to curb excessive prices, and reduce waste through simple, transparent rules and accountable outcomes. Within that framework, people should be able to choose among regulated public and private plans and local providers, with targeted help for low-income households and incentives that reward prevention and high-value care.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Government should guarantee a dependable, affordable baseline of essential healthcare so no one faces medical bankruptcy and everyone can access preventive, primary, mental-health, and emergency services. That public guarantee should be delivered with fiscal discipline—transparent pricing, negotiated drug and service costs, streamlined administration, and targeted subsidies for those who need help—so it is sustainable and accountable. Private and community providers should remain central through well‑regulated public–private partnerships that preserve meaningful patient choice, portability of coverage, and room for innovation while protecting the most vulnerable.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Government should ensure every resident has access to a basic, affordable level of essential healthcare—preventive care, primary and mental-health services, and true protection from catastrophic bills—so no family is pushed into financial ruin. That guarantee should be delivered with strict fiscal oversight: transparent pricing, negotiated drug and hospital costs, reduced paperwork, and strong anti-fraud enforcement. Private plans and local providers should remain part of the system, with portable coverage options and targeted subsidies so people can keep meaningful choice while no one is left without care.
